Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
IIP 1134684
University of Cincinnati; Lee

IIP 1134676
University of Michigan; Ni

IIP 1134721
Missouri University of Science and Technology; Sarangapani

The NSF Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) on Intelligent
Maintenance Systems (IMS) was established in 2001. This proposal builds upon the accomplishments of the previous ten years and seeks funding to continue supporting a three campus operation among the University of Cincinnati (leading institution), the University of Michigan, and Missouri Univ. of S&T.

The Center addresses the underlying issues in machine degradation modeling and prediction as well as develops the transformational technology in advanced prognostics. Over the past 10 years, the Center has developed systematic methodology and tools that made evident impacts to a number of member companies including Toyota, G.M., Boeing, P&G, and National Instruments, amongst others. Over the next five years, the Center intends to advance the scientific base as well as to validate the developed tools to further accelerate the deployment and commercialization of the developed technologies. The center also plans to have international sites in Singapore, Brazil and Spain. In addition, the Center plans to develop spin-off companies with a compelling Marketing Plan in order to commercialize its tools through its member company, National Instruments, in 2011.

The IMS IUCRC fills an important niche to maintain industry global competiveness by continuous improvement of manufacturing effectiveness and efficiency. The center educates students and its membership through an extensive system of internship and scholar exchanges as well as international workshops and courses. IMS has developed and continues to execute an effective system for innovation and IP generation. The Center plans to develop spin-off companies with a compelling Marketing Plan in order to commercialize its tools through its member company, National Instruments, in 2011.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF-I/UCRC for Intelligent Maintenance Systems (IMS) at the University of Michigan has operated successfully since 2001.  As a founding institute of this multi-campus I/UCRC, the IMS site at Michigan has contributed to the general success of this IMS center. Working closely with a large number of industrial member companies, including General Motors, Ford, Chrysler, Bosch, ETAS, General Electrics, Samsung, Eaton, Preh, Beijing Shenzhou Software, Zhejiang Lippo, Zhejiang Yunxia Group, BorgWarner, and BaoSteel, Michigan site has also supported a large number of MS and PhD graduates, as well as dozens of undergraduate student research projects.

The key outcomes of the IMS site at Michigan include the publication of over hundreds technical archival papers and student theses, the implementation of research findings at industrial companies, and the commercialization of the tools and methodologies generated from the IMS research. For example, General Motors has implemented IMS research results in over 22 of its North American plants and awarded three times of its highest technology implementation honors to the team who implemented the IMS research in 2005, 2006, and 2008. Ford Motor Company also implemented IMS research and selected the technology as one of the finalist for Henry Ford Technology Achievement award. General Electrics has also implemented some of the IMS research at its GE Aviation production equipment.

The IMS site at Michigan has also produced many outstanding talents for both industry and academia. Seven of its former PhD students are now faculty members at various national and international academic institutions. More are recruited by our member companies.

Overall, the IMS program has made significant impact on US industry's competitiveness by significantly improving the effectiveness of engineering assets, reducing unplanned downtime, increasing the reliability, and thus the quality and efficiency of these industrial applications.


Last Modified: 12/04/2018
Modified by: Jun Ni
